articles.headline: The Trump Effect on C.E.O. Pay
articles.snippet: A close look at the numbers suggests that the levitating 2016 stock market was a powerful driver of C.E.O. pay.
articles.abstract: A close look at the numbers suggests that the levitating 2016 stock market was a powerful driver of C.E.O. pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the November election, the stock market experienced a Trump bump. The surge in share prices thrilled investors, but some corporate executives had even more reason to celebrate. That’s because rising prices can fuel higher pay even if other corporate results are so-so, which seems to be the case for some companies right now.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: With a Presidential Boost, the P.G.A. Comes to Trump National
articles.snippet: The event, the Senior P.G.A. Championship, illustrates the pitfalls associated with a president unwilling to make a clean break with his commercial empire.
articles.abstract: The event, the Senior P.G.A. Championship, illustrates the pitfalls associated with a president unwilling to make a clean break with his commercial empire.
articles.lead_paragraph: STERLING, Va. — On the green at the 11th hole, the golf stars John Daly and Rocco Mediate sized up their opening tournament putts. Nearby, a Golf Channel crew swung its cameras into place. And a pack of spectators lined up to watch it all.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Steve Eder and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Your Coffee Is From Where? California?
articles.snippet: Farmers in Southern California are nurturing coffee bushes in what may be the first serious effort to commercialize beans from the contiguous United States.
articles.abstract: Farmers in Southern California are nurturing coffee bushes in what may be the first serious effort to commercialize beans from the contiguous United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOLETA, Calif. — There is a new crop growing in Southern California’s famous avocado groves — coffee.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Strom

articles.headline: Liberals Wanted a Fight in Montana. Democratic Leaders Saw a Lost Cause.
articles.snippet: Tension between party leaders who will not compete for unlikely seats and an energized base loath to concede anything to Republicans risks demoralizing activists.
articles.abstract: Tension between party leaders who will not compete for unlikely seats and an energized base loath to concede anything to Republicans risks demoralizing activists.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOZEMAN, Mont. — The Democratic defeat in a hard-fought special House election in Montana on Thursday highlighted the practical limitations on liberal opposition to President Trump and exposed a deepening rift between cautious party leaders, who want to pick their shots in battling for control of Congress in 2018, and more militant grass-roots activists who want to fight the Republicans everywhere.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Expecting a Big Economic Bump? It’s Looking Less Likely
articles.snippet: With headwinds from trade, forecasts for this quarter are turning more tepid and point to a continuation of steady but not stellar growth.
articles.abstract: With headwinds from trade, forecasts for this quarter are turning more tepid and point to a continuation of steady but not stellar growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: The big economic bounce that some experts have confidently predicted for later in the year may turn out to be only a small bump.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: A Russian Businessman’s Road From Siberia to Success
articles.snippet: A cosmetics company is a rare bright spot for a Russian economy that has been languishing in recent years.
articles.abstract: A cosmetics company is a rare bright spot for a Russian economy that has been languishing in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — He was rejected by the K.G.B. He couldn’t sell vodka to Russians. He went broke.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Coal Country’s Power Plants Are Turning Away From Coal
articles.snippet: Corporate demand for electricity from renewable sources to meet clean-energy goals is leading utilities to cut the use of a politically prized fuel.
articles.abstract: Corporate demand for electricity from renewable sources to meet clean-energy goals is leading utilities to cut the use of a politically prized fuel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Coal is on the defensive in the nation’s power industry. Even in coal country.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Mild in Mideast, Trump Is All Elbows in a Europe Eager to Jab Back
articles.snippet: The president played the statesman in the Middle East, but has switched to a familiar role, disrupter, as he joins the Group of 7 meeting, getting headlines like “Boor in Chief.”
articles.abstract: The president played the statesman in the Middle East, but has switched to a familiar role, disrupter, as he joins the Group of 7 meeting, getting headlines like “Boor in Chief.”
articles.lead_paragraph: TAORMINA, Sicily — “Trump shoves his allies,” read the front page of Belgium’s Le Soir. “Boor in chief” declared Germany’s financial newspaper Handelsblatt. An editorial in Le Monde called him “brutal and heavy-handed.”
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Kushner Is Said to Have Discussed a Secret Channel to Talk to Russia
articles.snippet: A back channel between Jared Kushner, a White House adviser, and Moscow was proposed to discuss Syria, but never pursued, in the weeks before Donald J. Trump’s inauguration.
articles.abstract: A back channel between Jared Kushner, a White House adviser, and Moscow was proposed to discuss Syria, but never pursued, in the weeks before Donald J. Trump’s inauguration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser, spoke in December with Russia’s ambassador to the United States about establishing a secret communications channel between the Trump transition team and Moscow to discuss strategy in Syria and other policy issues, according to three people with knowledge of the discussion.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Mark Mazzetti and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Zbigniew Brzezinski, National Security Adviser to Jimmy Carter, Dies at 89
articles.snippet: Mr. Brzezinski, who guided Mr. Carter during the Iran hostage crisis and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, had decades of influence in global affairs.
articles.abstract: Mr. Brzezinski, who guided Mr. Carter during the Iran hostage crisis and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, had decades of influence in global affairs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Zbigniew Brzezinski, the hawkish strategic theorist who was national security adviser to President Jimmy Carter in the tumultuous years of the Iran hostage crisis and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in the late 1970s, died on Friday at a hospital in Virginia. He was 89.
articles.byline: By Daniel Lewis

articles.headline: Is China Outsmarting America in A.I.?
articles.snippet: Its ambitions mingle sci-fi ideas and big money with the needs of an authoritarian state.
articles.abstract: Its ambitions mingle sci-fi ideas and big money with the needs of an authoritarian state.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Sören Schwertfeger finished his postdoctorate research on autonomous robots in Germany, and seemed set to go to Europe or the United States, where artificial intelligence was pioneered and established.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and John Markoff

articles.headline: Trump Ends Trip Where He Started: At Odds With Allies and Grilled on Russia
articles.snippet: Despite intense lobbying by world leaders, Mr. Trump did not endorse the Paris climate accords on the last day of his trip abroad.
articles.abstract: Despite intense lobbying by world leaders, Mr. Trump did not endorse the Paris climate accords on the last day of his trip abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAORMINA, Sicily — President Trump declined to endorse the Paris climate accords on Saturday, ending his first foreign trip much as he began it: at odds with several of the nation’s allies and under a cloud of questions back home about his ties to Russia.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Mark Landler

articles.headline: ‘Forgive Me’: Manchester Bomber’s Tangled Path of Conflict and Rebellion
articles.snippet: The life of Salman Abedi, the bomber whose attack killed 22 people in Manchester this past week, was interwoven with the tortured recent past of Libya.
articles.abstract: The life of Salman Abedi, the bomber whose attack killed 22 people in Manchester this past week, was interwoven with the tortured recent past of Libya.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Salman Abedi was wearing a red vest, his suicide bomb hidden in a small backpack, when he phoned his younger brother in Libya and asked him to put his mother on the line. It was about 10:20 p.m. on Monday, and the call was short.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold, Stephen Castle and Declan Walsh

articles.headline: Trump Returns to Crisis Over Kushner as White House Tries to Contain It
articles.snippet: President Trump arrived home Saturday to face reports that his son-in-law is under scrutiny in inquiries into possible ties between Russia and associates of Mr. Trump.
articles.abstract: President Trump arrived home Saturday to face reports that his son-in-law is under scrutiny in inquiries into possible ties between Russia and associates of Mr. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump returned home on Saturday to confront a growing political and legal threat, as his top aides tried to contain the fallout from reports that his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, is a focus of investigations into possible collusion between Russia and the president’s campaign and transition teams.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Glenn Thrush and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Route to Air Travel Discomfort Starts on Wall Street
articles.snippet: Investors’ relentless emphasis on the bottom line is fueling consumer frustration, and even episodes of air rage.
articles.abstract: Investors’ relentless emphasis on the bottom line is fueling consumer frustration, and even episodes of air rage.
articles.lead_paragraph: When an unlucky passenger was violently dragged off a full United Airlines flight in Chicago in April, setting off a public-relations nightmare for the company, the blame naturally fell on the cabin crew, the police and eventually airline executives.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Merkel, After Discordant G-7 Meeting, Is Looking Past Trump
articles.snippet: After President Trump declined to endorse NATO’s doctrine of collective defense and the Paris climate pact, the German leader said Europe should “take our fate into our own hands.”
articles.abstract: After President Trump declined to endorse NATO’s doctrine of collective defense and the Paris climate pact, the German leader said Europe should “take our fate into our own hands.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, Europe’s most influential leader, has concluded, after three days of trans-Atlantic meetings, that the United States of President Trump is not the reliable partner her country and the Continent have automatically depended on in the past.
articles.byline: By Alison Smale and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: The Coat of Arms Said ‘Integrity.’ Now It Says ‘Trump.’
articles.snippet: The emblem used by the Trump Organization in the United States had to be changed in Britain, since it belongs to another family.
articles.abstract: The emblem used by the Trump Organization in the United States had to be changed in Britain, since it belongs to another family.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — At the Trump National Golf Club outside Washington, which hosted the Senior P.G.A. Championship this weekend, the president’s coat of arms is everywhere — the sign out front, the pro shop, even the exercise room.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim

articles.headline: Army Fraud Crackdown Uses Broad Net to Catch Small Fish, Some Unfairly
articles.snippet: An inquiry into an incentive effort for the National Guard has targeted hundreds of soldiers and charged more than 150, but found only a fraction of the estimated fraud.
articles.abstract: An inquiry into an incentive effort for the National Guard has targeted hundreds of soldiers and charged more than 150, but found only a fraction of the estimated fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: AGUAS BUENAS, Puerto Rico — Federal agents with body armor and assault rifles stormed a small house in this hillside town on a dark October night two years ago, intent on arresting a retired National Guard captain suspected of an elaborate scheme to defraud the military. But in a sign of larger problems to come in the investigation, they raided the wrong house. Twice.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps

articles.headline: Hackers Hide Cyberattacks in Social Media Posts
articles.snippet: A recent attack on the accounts of Defense Department employees suggests how easily people can be duped into clicking on dangerous links.
articles.abstract: A recent attack on the accounts of Defense Department employees suggests how easily people can be duped into clicking on dangerous links.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It took only one attempt for Russian hackers to make their way into the computer of a Pentagon official. But the attack didn’t come through an email or a file buried within a seemingly innocuous document.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: The Future of European Transit: Driverless and Utilitarian
articles.snippet: Across Europe, some fledgling driverless projects are focused on utilitarian self-driving vehicles for mass transit that barely exceed walking pace.
articles.abstract: Across Europe, some fledgling driverless projects are focused on utilitarian self-driving vehicles for mass transit that barely exceed walking pace.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the outskirts of Berlin, Michael Barillère-Scholz is testing a driverless vehicle that is neither sleek nor futuristic. The machine is boxy and painted white. Its top speed barely reaches 20 miles per hour.
articles.byline: By Mark Scott

articles.headline: In China, Umbrellas and Basketballs Join the Sharing Economy
articles.snippet: Buoyed by the success of car- and bike-sharing companies and fueled with cash, Chinese start-ups are entering what some see as a sharing bubble.
articles.abstract: Buoyed by the success of car- and bike-sharing companies and fueled with cash, Chinese start-ups are entering what some see as a sharing bubble.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China may be oversharing.
articles.byline: By Amy Qin

articles.headline: Jared Kushner’s Role Is Tested as Russia Case Grows
articles.snippet: It is unclear how Jared Kushner’s high-profile woes will affect his hard-won partnership with his father-in-law, perhaps the most stable in an often unstable White House.
articles.abstract: It is unclear how Jared Kushner’s high-profile woes will affect his hard-won partnership with his father-in-law, perhaps the most stable in an often unstable White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The most successful deal of Jared Kushner’s short and consequential career in real estate and politics involves one highly leveraged acquisition: a pair of adjoining offices a few penny-loafer paces from his father-in-law’s desk in the White House.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Maggie Haberman and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Foot Soldiers in a Shadowy Battle Between Russia and the West
articles.snippet: Freelance agitators promote Russia’s agenda abroad, getting their backing from tycoons and others, not the state itself.
articles.abstract: Freelance agitators promote Russia’s agenda abroad, getting their backing from tycoons and others, not the state itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: MELNIK, Czech Republic — Working at his computer, as he does most weekends, on an anti-Western diatribe for a Czech website, Ladislav Kasuka was not sure what to make of the messages that began popping up on his Facebook page, offering him money to organize street protests.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins

articles.headline: North Korean Tests Add Urgency for U.S. to Fix Defense Flaws
articles.snippet: The North has recently test-fired missiles based on a technology that would give the United States little warning of an attack. And they seem to work.
articles.abstract: The North has recently test-fired missiles based on a technology that would give the United States little warning of an attack. And they seem to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Pentagon prepares to conduct its first test in three years of the multibillion-dollar effort to intercept a North Korean warhead, it hopes to demonstrate that it has fixed a system that has worked in fewer than half of its previous nine tests.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
